svg.title: Rendering your first triangles in OpenGL

text.tspan: Binary data describing zero or more attributes
for each vertex. Position and color are common.
The layout of each record will be specified later.
A shader defines a function which is called at
some point in the graphics pipeline, depending
on its type. It transforms input of some kind
into output of the required kind.
Before using the data, we need to upload it to a
GPU-managed buffer. usage is a hint about how
we intend to access the buffer's data.
Before using the shader, we need to compile it.
For convenience, we can pass NULL as size
if the string is NUL terminated.
Rendering your first triangles in OpenGL
We link one shader of each type into a complete
The core profile requires a VAO
Ownership (after each step, the previous object can be deleted)
Each attribute array can use different VBOs
The vertex shader references attribute arrays through their indexes
We unpack the binary data into many attribute
arrays. Each attribute array is identified by an
index num, and has a value for each vertex:
stride, offset say where it is in the buffer
components, type say what the value is
Once the code (program) and data (VAO) are
ready, we can render vertices to the framebuffer.
offset, count specify a subarray of vertices from the VAO.
(holds the rendered result, and is usually
created and bound when setting up the

cc:Work.dc:title: Rendering your first triangles in OpenGL
